content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: All of the above

I like it very much, because the naive first ideas might be complicated whereas there is in fact a simple solution.

However I think the description is difficult to understand. I think the sentence "Each of these lines consists of the chars and the missing chars" is confusing. In the description of the input, "Each of these lines consists of the missing chars" is wrong. What do you think of something like: "Each of these lines is a representation of a row of the keyboard, where missing keys are represented with '*'"? Then the example makes it very clear.

Maybe you could also add that the keyboard may not be a US "qwerty" keyboard.

In addition, I think the examples allow to understand the puzzle, so I would suggest it for reverse mode too.

'Expect 3 lines. Each of these lines consists of the missing chars in the order they are presented on the keyboard.'

This doesn't make sense to me. Missing chars are not in the input. They are missing.
I understood the problem immediately from the input/output example but I think the statement itself should be reworded to be more clear. Also dvorak test seems unnecessary to me. I personally wouldn't base my solution on keyboard layout but if someone would, this might be very confusing for them, especially since not everyone knows about the existence of such layout.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution

Very cool! However I did NOT expect the keyboard layout to suddenly change to dvorak right at the end, which broke my initial solution. If there was a mention of that in the goal, I would have crafted my solution otherwise and not run out of time trying to fix what I had.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because i think it is solvable and fun to deal with it.

In order to make the input at first glance seem to be a little more complex to work with and more "keyboard like" it might be an idea to cascade the input like keycaps:
like: [q] [w] [e] * [t]
or: [q] [w] [e] [*] [t]

Additionaly you could leave a blank at the beginning of second row and 2 blanks in third row. feels keeb man

This does not make the processing any harder but I think it looks more tricky and gets closer to the task's description :)

Good job, man!

I really think it has no relation with the keyboard as nothing changed in the statement related to the keyboard, nor in the outputs.
It is just a matter of checking if a letter is in a string that you will create by joining the 3 lists. While I think it could be approved for its simplicity, the statement is not very related of what you really want.

In current version there is actually no relation to the keyboard as such: all you need is to check which abcs are missing out of 26. I would approve this contribution if you fix the statement to mention it (and avoid any relation to keyboard).
But the description makes me think that the idea behind was different. Personally after reading the statement I  expected the output chars to be sorted  in the order they are missing. I would change the expected output to:
expect 3 lines. Each of these lines consists of the missing chars in the order they are presented on the keyboard.

All in all, I see some contradiction here. 
This is only my personal opinion. Good luck!

Thanks for the feedback!
I updated the contribution by your suggestions.
